de.uka.ipd.sdq.beagle.core.failurehandling

Class FailureHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • de.uka.ipd.sdq.beagle.core.failurehandling.FailureHandler
  • Direct Known Subclasses:
    ExceptionThrowingFailureHandler

    public abstract class FailureHandler
extends Object
    Handler for any failures that may occur while running Beagle. Clients may obtain an instance of this class to report that an exceptional situation occurred.

    Failures reported through this API may be recoverable. This means that Beagle’s execution does not have to be stopped and that there is a way to continue without or to retry the failed action. Recoverable failures are handled by recover functions that may optionally return a value to continue with after the failure.

    The reaction to failures can be configured by providing a FailureHandler.FailureHandlerProvider at setProvider(FailureHandlerProvider). If no provider is configured, a ExceptionThrowingFailureHandler will be returned by getHandler(java.lang.String).

    Given that the class has a failure handler defined in the constant FAILURE_HANDLER, these are some usage examples: 

     
 public ReturnType myMethod(ParameterType1 param1, ParameterType2 param2) {
        // code
        try {
                // code that may fail
        } catch (MyExceptionType exception) {
                final FailureReport<ReturnTyp> failure = new FailureReport<>()
                        .message("doing something with %s and %s failed", param1, param2)
                        .cause(exception)
                        .recoverable()
                        .retryWith(() -< myMethod(param1, param2));
                return FAILURE_HANDLER.handle(failure);
        }
        // more code
 }
 
 
     
 public ReturnType myMethod(ParameterType1 param1, ParameterType2 param2) {
        // code
        if (failed) {
                final FailureReport<Void> failure = new FailureReport<>()
                        .message("doing something with %s and %s failed", param1, param2)
                        .details("We tried this and that, but doing so was not possible")
                        .continueWith(this::otherMethod);
                FAILURE_HANDLER.handle(failure);
                return null;
        }
        // more code
 }

    • Method Detail

      • getHandler

        public static FailureHandler getHandler(String clientName)
        Creates a handler a client identified by clientName may report failures to.
        Parameters:
        clientName - A name identifying the client that may report failures to this handler. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        A handler for failures of a client called clientName.

      • getHandler

        public static FailureHandler getHandler(Class<?> clientType)
        Creates a handler instances of clientType may report failures to.
        Parameters:
        clientType - Class of the clients that may report failures to this handler. Must not be null.
        Returns:
        A handler for failures of clients assignable to clientType.

      • setProvider

        public static void setProvider(FailureHandler.FailureHandlerProvider provider)
        Sets the provider of Failure Handlers. The provider will be used to generate all future handlers until the next call to this method.
        Parameters:
        provider - A factory for handlers. Must not be null.

      • handle

        public abstract <RECOVER_TYPE> RECOVER_TYPE handle(FailureReport<RECOVER_TYPE> report)
        Reports a failure to this handler and makes it take action. This may include calling the recover functions potentially provided through report. This method will return the value generated by the recover functions. If the report describes a non-recoverable failure, this method will not return. This method might also not return if the handler thinks it’s not appropraite to continue.
        Type Parameters:
        RECOVER_TYPE - The recover value’s type.
        Parameters:
        report - Information about the failure.
        Returns:
        The value the reporter should use instead of the one that was expected to be generated by the failed action. Is created by the recover functions in report.
